did.abstract: Republican member of the Michigan House of Representatives. Legislative files, 1967-1974, concerning in part his interest in water pollution legislation; political files concerning election campaigns, and involvement in Ann Arbor and Washtenaw County, Michigan, Republican Party activities; and photographs.
did.physloc: offsite storage; prior notification required for access

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The major portion of the collection was received in 1975. A smaller addition came in 1982. Donor no. 5764.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Raymond J. Smit Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Raymond J. Smit was born on September 21, 1928 in Detroit, Michigan. He received degrees in civil engineering (B.A., 1950; M. A., 1955) from the University of Michigan. Upon graduation, he took a position at Ayres, Lewis, Norris, and May, a firm of consulting engineers, Ann Arbor, Michigan.

Raymond Smit's political activities began in the late 1950s when he became involved in Ann Arbor and Washtenaw County Republican affairs. From 1958 to 1962, he worked for the campaign committees of various Republican candidates for local offices, and served as director of Ann Arbor's Fifth Ward Republican Committee. In December 1962, he became chairman of the Ann Arbor Republican Committee, and served in that position until May 1965. In addition, he served on the Ann Arbor Housing and Zoning Board of Appeals from 1961 to 1966. As a reward for his service to the party, Smit was chosen to be an alternate delegate to the 1964 Republican National Convention.

Raymond Smit was first elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in 1966 from the 53rd district, which then consisted of Ann Arbor city and township. Subsequently, he was re-elected in 1968 and 1970. In 1972, he was elected from the newly altered 52nd district which included only a small portion of Ann Arbor along with new territory added to the district primarily in eastern Washtenaw County.

As a State Representative, Raymond Smith served on the following House Standing Committees: Conservation, Environment, and Recreation; State Affairs; Colleges and Universities; Economic Development; and Roads and Bridges. During his years in office, he sponsored and authored legislation relating to his various committee assignments. Legislation in the area of air and water pollution control was his primary interest. In 1968, he was the chief sponsor of Michigan's pollution control bond issue. The bond issue, once approved by the voters of Michigan, was implemented through enactment of new laws and amendments or revisions of existing statutes.

Smit was also the prime sponsor of what was dubbed as the "Truth in Water Pollution" bill that initiated a new concept of pollution surveillance. Through this legislation, industry was to pay the cost of monitoring its uses of state water resources. In 1974, Smit retired from the State House in order to pursue his career in civil engineering.

scopecontent.p: The Raymond Smit collection consists entirely of materials generated during his eight years in the Michigan House of Representatives, 1967-1974. The series in the collection are Legislative files which consists of subject files and bills files; Personal Materials; Political Files (1960-1975); Legislative Special Topics Files (1967-1974); and Photographs

The principal series - Legislative files - is arranged at first by single year and then by two-year term. This series is further divided into two categories of materials. One of these is a set of numbered files arranged for the most part by department within the state government. These files contain a variety of documents, such as correspondence with fellow legislators, constituents, and lobbying groups, as well as office memos, reports, and relevant background information on a particular issue. The following is a list of the headings (with the corresponding file number) used by Smit and his staff.
Administration, Dept. of [file no. 1]
Agriculture, Dept. of [file no. 2]
Attorney General [file no. 3]
Auditor General [file no. 4]
Civil Rights, Dept. of [file no. 5]
Civil Service, Dept. of [file no. 6]
Commerce, Dept. of [file no. 7]
Corrections, Dept. of [file no. 8]
Education, Dept. of [file no. 9]
Labor, Dept. of [file no. 10]
Licensing and Regulation, Dept. of [file no. 11]
Mental Health, Dept. of [file no. 12]
Military Affairs, Dept. of [file no. 13]
Natural Resources, Dept. of [file no. 14]
Public Health, Dept. of [file no. 15]
Social Services, Dept. of [file no. 16]
State, Dept. of [file no. 17]
State Highways, Dept. of [file no. 18]
State Police, Dept. of [file no. 19]
Treasury, Dept. of [file no. 20]
Executive Department [file no. 21]
Judiciary [file no. 22]
Legislative Affairs [file no. 23]
Local Government [file no. 24]
National Affairs [file no. 25]
Republican Party [file no. 26]
Speeches [file no. 27]
Personal [file no. 28]

The second category of files within the Legislative file is Smit's Bills File. These files are arranged by legislative session and include background information, committee reports, and correspondence. They are further arranged in order of the assigned bill number.

did.unittitle: 1973-1974 Committee on Conservation, Environment, and Recreation
1973-1974 Committee to Study Northwestern Highway Extension

scopecontent.p: The Personal Materials are mainly biographical sketches and clippings about Smit's life and career.

Political Files has two subseries based on geographical areas: Ann Arbor and Washtenaw County Files, and State and National Files. The Ann Arbor and Washtenaw County files provide some insight Into Smit's early political career on behalf of local Republican organizations. The State and National subseries relates to Smit's political activities while in the Michigan House of Representatives. Some of the more important files included in this subseries concern Smit's campaigns for election, his retirement announcement in 1974, his being considered for a position in the Environmental Protection Agency (1973), and his activities on behalf of former Governor William Milliken. The kinds of material found in the political files include correspondence, news clippings, reports, and texts of speeches.

did.unittitle: Civil Rights and Fair Housing Laws 1963
Letter to University of Michigan President, March 30, 1970
Certificate of election and news articles
Speech before U.S. House of Representatives Subcommittee on Water Resources, Public Works Committee 1973
Task Force on Water Rights, Use, and Pollution Control 1965

scopecontent.p: The Legislative special topics files mainly concern the pollution control bond issue. They are generally arranged alphabetically by subject for each specific legislative session.

did.unittitle: Outline of Clean Water Bond Program
Special Legislative Committee on Peerless Cement Company

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series includes portraits; and photographs of Michigan industries and waterways, notably the Peerless Cement Company in Detroit and Red Run Drain in Madison Heights.
